qas.question: What production trait existed in tribal groups that were controlled by charismatic leaders?
What theory describes the implied egalitarianism of Neolithic societies?
What type of disagreement existed in tribal groups that were controlled by charismatic leaders?
What production trait existed in tribal groups that were controlled by Neolithic leaders?
What theory describes the implied egalitarianism of labor societies?
What type of disagreement existed in tribal groups that were controlled by Neolithic groups?

plausible_answers.text: the Marxist concept of primitive communism

qas.question: What is a theory that has explained the egalitarianism of labor societies?

plausible_answers.text: that Neolithic societies functioned under any dominating class or individual

context: <a0_0><b3_0>Control of labour<b3_0/><a0_0/> and <a2_0><b5_0>inter-group conflict<b5_0/><a2_0/> is characteristic of corporate-level or 'tribal' groups, headed by a charismatic individual; whether a 'big man' or a proto-chief, functioning as a lineage-group head. Whether a non-hierarchical system of organization existed is debatable, and there is no evidence that explicitly suggests <b7_0>that Neolithic societies functioned under any dominating class or individual<b7_0/>, as was the case in the chiefdoms of the European Early Bronze Age. Theories to explain the apparent implied egalitarianism of Neolithic (and Paleolithic) societies have arisen, notably <b6_0>the <a1_0><b4_0>Marxist concept of primitive communism<b6_0/><b4_0/><a1_0/>.
